notes: 'Restaurants are limited to 50 percent capacity and can only operate between the hours of 6a.m. and 9p.m(restaurants must close their dining rooms at 9p.m., although they are permitted to offer take out through 10p.m.).  Stores, including supermarkets, cannot stay open beyond 7p.m.'  https://web.archive.org/save/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'Museums and monuments, cultural and art fairs, and libraries and media centers are also limited to 50 percent capacity. Movie theaters remain closed and religious activities have been suspended. Access to beaches, public swimming pools, and all naval clubs is prohibited through October 15, 2020.  Schools are permitted to hold classes virtually only, and not in person.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200831105437/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'The Angolan government has established quarantine areas: one, encompassing Luanda Province, and the second, around the municipality of Cazengo in Cuanza Norte province. Criminal charges may be brought against anyone who leaves the quarantine area. Within these areas, strict measures are in place to limit the spread of COVID-19.'  https://web.archive.org/web/20200831105437/https://ao.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'Angolaâs borders remain closed. Entry to Angola is prohibited except for Angolan nationals and foreign nationals resident in Angola.'  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/angola/entry-requirementsormation

The ministry of education is planning for the reopening of the schools for the new academic year.  While waiting for the presidentâs pronouncement on the fate of the 2020 academic year, the ministry of education is preparing for strategies in case schools will be reopened. The reopening will mainly focus on finalists and candidate classes. There will be major reviews of the daily school routines to provide for shorter and core curriculum school days with classes scheduled between 8:00 am and 1:30 pm.   The ministry is also preparing to roll out the second phase of the home-schooling programme with the national curriculum development centre currently develop reading materials for the entire academic which will be given out to all learners across the country.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200903000814/https://observer.ug/news/headlines/66239-school-reopening-only-15-students-to-be-allowed-per-classroom

Most businesses in the rest of the country have been able to resume.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200902233804/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12   The majority of shops, banks and restaurants continue to operate, with precautionary measures in place including legislation that makes it compulsory to wear face coverings in public places, businesses and common areas of residential buildings.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200903005122/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

Meetings of more than 50 people remain prohibited, religious meetings have been permitted with limits on capacity and whilst following social distancing regulations.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200902233804/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12

The total lockdown in Gaborone was lifted on August 13, but restrictions remain in place nationwide. Meeting of more than 50 people remain prohibited.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200902233804/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12

According to the US embassy, buses and van are operating at full capacity, but masks are required at all times on public transportation.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200903005255/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

The country has been divided into nine COVID-19 zones, with permits required to travel between the zones.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200902233804/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12   http://web.archive.org/web/20200903005122/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus

International flights remain suspended and land borders are closed. Humanitarian, cargo, and repatriation flights have continued, though those traveling from high-risk countries are not permitted entry.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200902233804/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/369236/botswana-authorities-lift-lockdown-in-gaborone-august-13-update-12   There are no commercial flights in to or out of Botswana. The Botswana authorities have also closed land border posts with neighbouring countries.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200903005122/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/coronavirus
No new update.

"The government has restricted internal travel and ordered new arrivals from abroad to quarantine for up to 21 days. Schools, bars and places of worship have been told to close, and gatherings of more than 15 people have been banned. But recently published photos show daily life in Bangui continuing as normal for many, with people crowded in markets and congregating inside bars that, from the outside, purport to be closed."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903132746/https://www.aljazeera.com/indepth/features/central-african-republic-colossal-struggle-covid-19-200421142222924.html

On 12 June, the Central African Republic government announced the entry into âphase twoâ of the COVID-19 response, which includes the reopening of places of worship and restaurants. The following measures remain in place:    It is obligatory to wear face masks in public places;  No handshakes or kissing, instead use non-contact greetings for social interactions;  No large gatherings;  Public spaces must have hand-washing stations;    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903131750/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/coronavirus

"More than one million people informed about COVID-19 and barrier gestures  In addition to the assistance given to communities, more than 900 community, religious or civil society leaders, weapon bearers, local authorities or community members were alerted to the dangers of the disease in order that they in turn can pass on the right information. They learned handwashing technique and received posters, leaflets, handwashing equipment, kettles and soap so that they can launch and continue awareness-raising activities in their communities"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903150029/https://www.icrc.org/en/document/central-african-republic-contending-covid-19-midst-serious-humanitarian-crisis

Economic Funds, announced on March 31st, including support for both informal and formal sector workers, remain in place. âThe authorities created 4 special Funds to be spent over 2 years, including the National Solidarity Fund of 170 billion CFAF (0.5 % of GDP), the Support Fund for the informal sector of 100 billion CFAF (0.3 % of GDP), the Support Fund for the small and medium enterprises of 150 billion CFAF (0.4 % of GDP) and the Support Fund for large companies of 100 billion CFAF (0.3 % of GDP). They will also provide financial support to the agriculture sector by 300 billion CFAF (0.8 % of GDP).â Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200831144153/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

âThe regional central bank (BCEAO) for the West-African Economic and Monetary Union (WAEMU)â¦Â set-up a framework inviting banks and microfinance institutions to accommodate demands from customers with Covid19-related repayment difficulties to postpone for a 3 month renewable period debt service falling due, without the need to classify such postponed claims as non-performingâ. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200831144153/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  Also, the government previously announced the âpostponement of deadlines for payment of electricity and water bills from April to July 2020 and from May to August 2020â, which remains current. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200831181944/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/ivory-coast-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html

No change. The government of the DRC relaxed the health-related State of Emergency that was put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Schools, universities, and places of worship have reopened.       http://web.archive.org/web/20200904081808/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change. The government of the DRC relaxed the health-related State of Emergency that was put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Shops, banks, restaurants, bars, and public transport reopened July 22.  Schools, universities, and places of worship are allowed to reopen.  Airports, ports, borders and places of worship reopened August 15.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200904081808/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change. The government of the DRC relaxed the health-related State of Emergency that was put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Shops, banks, restaurants, bars, and public transport reopened July 22. Masks continue to be required on public transport.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200904081808/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy. There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel however domestic travellers continue to be required to present a negative COVID-19 test for travel.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200904081808/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No change in policy. All travellers entering the DRC, regardless of the origin of their travel, are required to self-quarantine in their residence or hotel for 14 day upon arrival.   http://web.archive.org/web/20200904081808/https://cd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

No policy change. Pointe-Noire: National Public Health Laboratory located at: HÃ´pital General de Loandili or Laboratoire de la foundation Gombes.  Congolese authorities implemented mandatory testing upon airport arrival and identified quarantine sites in Brazzaville and Pointe-Noire. University students have returned to face-to-face teaching on August 24. All other school levels seem to remain closed, hence 2G:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200824225652/https://www.msn.com/en-xl/africa/ghana/4-critical-updates-akufo-addo-gave-ghanaians-in-his-15th-covid-19-address/ar-BB1825P1

The President of Ghana announced in his speech on 30 August that, 'with Junior High Schools operating with class sizes of thirty, and Senior High Schools with class sizes of twenty-five', students will 'return to school from 5th October to 14th December 2020 to complete their academic year', and to 'write their end of term examinations'. Nurseries, kindergartens, and primary schools might not resumed until January 2021.    https://archive.vn/sJY1N

'Ghana is reopening its main airport to international flight passengers from Sept. 1 ... Any passenger arriving in Ghana will have to present a negative Covid-19 result, taken no more than 72 hours before departure from the country of origin, President Nana Akufo-Addo said in a broadcast Sunday. Upon arrival, passengers will again be tested at the airport, with results to be provided within 30 minutes. International travel by land and sea are still prohibited.'  https://archive.vn/mFF9B    The President's speech on 30 August: https://archive.vn/sJY1N
Some schools and places of worship reopened in June in areas without recent Covid-19 infections.  https://archive.vn/Umjtw

Analamanga: As their high school reopened after being closed for a month due to the coronavirus, students in Madagascar's capital city were given face masks and a small bottle of an herbal extract they were told to drink to protect them from Covid-19. Many grimacing at its bitter taste, the students swallowed the drink and entered school to resume classes, where they were now seated one to a desk instead of two, for safer distance. Madagascar's President Andry Rajoelina promoted the drink, Covid Organics, on national television saying it will "change the course of history. http://web.archive.org/web/20200830181046/https://www.news18.com/news/world/it-will-change-the-course-of-history-madagascars-president-touts-herbal-drink-against-covid-19-2596005.html    June 12: Madagascar Country Office Covid-19 response   UNICEF also pursues advocacy, support and service delivery to ensure that  the children of Madagascar, the poorest country in East Africa, are not  further impacted by common diseases, such as malaria, or by the  disruption of essential services. Madagascar is one of the few countries in  the region that reopened schools for some grades, with UNICEF support for  alternative education.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200617185615/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/UNICEF%20Madagascar%20COVID-19%20Situation%20Report%20-%2012%20June%202020.pdf

"Most business operations will resume until 18:00. Authorities also announced that domestic flights providing connections between Antananarivo and Sambava, Antsiranana, Tolagnaro, Toliara, Nosy Be, Toamasina, Mahajanga, Sainte Marie, Maroantsetra, and Morondava, will begin to operate from September 1. Travelers will be required to provide a negative PCR test acquired less than 48 hours prior to their departure. Additional screening measures will also be implemented. International flight operations remain suspended.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200830181552/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/371926/madagascar-authorities-ease-measures-and-extend-national-state-of-health-emergency-through-september-7-update-16

Public campaign over social media including statistics  https://www.facebook.com/minsanp/    However, appears to be division between Ministry of Health and office of the President in public message, particularly over the amount of protection that an herbal cure promoted by the President offers.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200820161352/https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-africa-53756752    https://africa.cgtn.com/2020/07/23/madagascar-split-after-health-minister-requests-international-help-to-fight-covid-19/

On June 18 the Prime Minister clarified that not everyone can be screened but only those suspected of having the disease or symptoms and those who have been in contact with it. The government is also making a big effort to build a PCR laboratory in Toamasina, which is closer to the Analanjirofo region.    http://archive.vn/Ik8Oq

"Madagascar tapped into a network of community health volunteers who were ready to step in when the outbreak hit. Those volunteers go door to door in communities across the country as health educators. They make sure pregnant women get pre-natal care and children are vaccinated. They treat common ailments, such as malaria, diarrhea and pneumonia. "They're the eyes and ears of the health system," said John Yanulis, who directed the program for the nonprofit Management Sciences for Health. "They are trusted members of their community."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200830184317/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/how-contact-tracers-could-help-control-covid-19    However, there is no stringent policy on contact tracing.

According to updates of the U.S. Embassy in Mauritania on 3 September:  Limited commercial flights are available; a negative COVID-19 test (PCR and/or serology) required for entry; health screening procedures are in place at airports and other ports of entry; and U.S. citizens are not required to quarantine (should be the same to citizens of other nations; there is no mention of a 'green list').    https://archive.vn/fTcOa

The borders remain closed, however, exceptions for repatriation are in place.    The government has announced that "Mauritius is reopening its borders in three phases and the protection of the population remains the priority in the face of the COVID-19 pandemic. The first phase comprises the repatriation of Mauritians stranded abroad which will continue until 30 September 2020. Arriving passengers will continue to be quarantined in the centers made available by the State.  The second phase will start on 01 October 2020 during which travel to and from certain destinations will be allowed. Access to the Mauritian territory will be authorised to passengers abiding by sanitary protocols. Online booking for airline tickets and hotel room reservations would be available. However, priority will be given to Mauritian nationals, licensed residents, those employed in Mauritius and other visitors wishing to travel to Mauritius.  The third phase of reopening the borders will be determined in the light of the evolution of the COVID-19 pandemic."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200904194515/http://www.govmu.org/English/News/Pages/COVID-19-Mauritius-to-reopen-borders-in-three-phases-.aspx  http://web.archive.org/web/20200904200856/https://www.lexpress.mu/article/381993/frontieres-mauriciennes-restent-fermees-jusquau-31-octobre-2020  http://web.archive.org/web/20200904193637/https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

'Authorities in Rwanda on Thursday [3 September] announced new guidelines stipulating fines for people violating health measures put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Private businesses using more than 50% of existing employees will be fined 150,000 Rwandan francs (about $155).'    https://archive.vn/yzs3v

'Authorities in Rwanda on Thursday [3 September] announced new guidelines stipulating fines for people violating health measures put in place to prevent the spread of COVID-19. Hosting mass gatherings for events such as birthday parties or bridal and baby showers will lead to a fine of 200,000 Rwandan francs (about $207). People who attend these events will be liable to pay 25,000 Rwandan francs ($25). Places of worship that reopen without permission will be fined 150,000 Rwandan francs (about $155), while those allowed to reopen will have to pay 100,000 Rwandan francs (about $104) if safety rules are breached.'    https://archive.vn/yzs3v

The government has removed mandatory 14-day quarantine requirements for visitors on arrival, as well as the requirement for a negative COVID-19 test. However, temperature screening for passengers on arrival is being implemented. If visitors show symptoms of COVID-19 on arrival, they may undergo enhanced screening and be required to take a Covid-19 test, followed by a 14-day self-isolation, depending on the result.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200826133041/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tanzania

On July 21, President Museveni announced the government would allow shopping arcades and beauty salons to reopen immediately following an earlier lifting of some lockdown measures such as a ban on the use of private vehicles and closure of most stores. The government also allowed motorcycle taxi (boda boda) drivers to resume carrying passengers as of July 27 and the curfew was shortened to 2100h-0530h.? Schools, churches, and mosques remain closed. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903121747/https://ug.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-page/

Shopping arcades, hairdressers and salons will be open from 22 July.  Shopping malls, supermarkets and pharmacies are open.  Hotels and restaurants are open with social distancing measures in place and food delivery services (such as Jumia) remain operational outside of curfew hours. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200820114638/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/uganda/staying-during-coronavirus

Gatherings of more than 5 people are still prohibited. Public exercise is still banned.   Schools, churches, and mosques remain closed. Public transport is generally allowed at half-capacity and all passengers are required to wear masks. Private vehicles are allowed to carry only four passengers, including a driver. Public transport operators are expected to provide sanitization, passengers are required to wear masks, and seating is limited to half regular capacity. As of August 18th level 2 restrictions are in place. Things like retail stores and other businesses can open, while others like nightclubs still remain closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/    Announcement of transition to level 2:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200819072930/https://www.gov.za/sites/default/files/gcis_document/202008/43620gon891s_0.pdf
Public events and gatherings are prohibited under level 2 restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/
All public gatherings are prohibited under level 2 restrictions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/
No new policy found

Under level 2 restrictions it is required to say home unless you have essential work or to purchase goods.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/
Interprovincial travel is permitted under the level 2 restrictions as of August 18th.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/

Border is not open apart for South Africans returning home and foreign nationals leaving South Africa.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200824222049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/covid-19-risk-adjusted-strategy/
No policy change
No policy change

On September 1 they launched a new contact tracing tool to improve the process.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903211049/https://sacoronavirus.co.za/2020/09/01/department-of-health-launches-powerful-new-tool-to-strengthen-covid-19-contact-tracing/

Schools at all levels remain closed in zimbabwe. The minister of education announced the reopening of schools scheduled for 14th of September.    https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-09/02/c_139335333.htm

The curfew has been shortened to 20:00 to 06:00 to allow people more time during the day. This increased business hours.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820114321/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/370591/zimbabwe-authorities-reduce-covid-19-curfew-hours-august-18-update-13

All Public Events remain cancelled. This includes weddings, funerals and religious events.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820114321/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/370591/zimbabwe-authorities-reduce-covid-19-curfew-hours-august-18-update-13

the government has prohibited its citizens from all local and international travel, and banned all gatherings of more than 100 people, including church services, weddings, funerals, and all international sporting events.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/324186/zimbabwe-authorities-declare-state-of-disaster-and-ban-gatherings-of-more-than-100-people-as-of-march-17

Some modes of public transport are banned in Zimbabwe. Most people have to use private vehicles which now act as the main mode of public transport.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200829050022/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/zimbabwe-s-banned-kombi-operators-turn-vehicles-to-mobile-stores/1889248

There remains a curfew and only people providing essential services are allowed to operate. Most people would therefore be required to stay at home.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820114321/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/370591/zimbabwe-authorities-reduce-covid-19-curfew-hours-august-18-update-13

The ban on inter-regional travel remains in place. Some people need special permits to travel across regions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200820114321/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/370591/zimbabwe-authorities-reduce-covid-19-curfew-hours-august-18-update-13

All borders remain closed in Zimbabwe.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/  https://web.archive.org/web/20200820114321/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/370591/zimbabwe-authorities-reduce-covid-19-curfew-hours-august-18-update-13

Income support measures include:   A cash transfer program that targeting 1 million vulnerable households and a larger COVID-19 economic recovery and stimulus package. The package covered various sectors and included communities affected by cyclone idai  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903170940/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There are lending facilities for the private sector but they have not been described as debt relief measures  https://web.archive.org/web/20200903170940/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19

There is a good public health information campaign to inform all interested parties on new developments. Importantly, the public is made aware of all new policies.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200903204928/https://zw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information-2/

Zimbabwe is noted to have limited testing capacity and poor contact tracing systems. This reduces the number of tests they will conduct and affects their testing policy  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)31751-7/fulltext#%20
Zimbabwe is noted to have poor contact tracing systems.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.thelancet.com/journals/lancet/article/PIIS0140-6736(20)31751-7/fulltext#%20
